I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
transformed_texts:
My neighborhood's a real melting pot, crammed into this big city.  You've got houses scattered here and there, kinda randomly, between shops and offices and all sorts of places to eat and have fun.  There's never a shortage of new restaurants popping up, and you can find everything from massive chain stores to cute little boutiques. These boutiques aren't just in malls, either - they're all over the place, bringing a bit of buzz to neighborhoods that'd otherwise be pretty quiet.

We've got a couple of parks nearby, and it's always cool to see families hanging out there with their kids. The people themselves are super diverse, too.  One little area has a big LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a bunch of folks who came from the former Soviet Union.

Not too far outside my neighborhood, you've got all sorts of other cultures hanging out in their own little pockets - Korean Town, China Town, Little Armenia, and more. But even though these areas are close by, getting around can be a nightmare. Traffic is insane, especially during rush hour - ten miles can take you two hours!  Most people here drive everywhere, so walking isn't really an option.

The city's HUGE, and we're constantly adding more apartment buildings, which is great for some people but kinda stressful for those of us worried about even more traffic.  

But hey, not everyone wants to live in a massive apartment building. There are tons of houses of all sizes scattered around, plus smaller apartment complexes and condos. You've got single-family homes, duplexes - all sorts of options.  

My neighborhood's got people of all ages, but it's not really the tight-knit community it used to be.  I remember playing outside with my neighbor and a few other kids when I was younger, but these days, most of my neighbors are strangers.

My neighborhood is a snapshot of Americana, full of single-family homes with a few split into doubles, clinging to the idea of the suburban dream.  My place has a little front yard and a tiny driveway, a throwback to a time when this kind of life was the epitome of success.  You can almost feel the dream fading, though.  The houses still stand, a testament to a time when hope was stronger, but the yards aren't kept up like they used to be, and there's a sense of resignation in the air. You still see kids playing, seemingly oblivious to the world's worries, and the 90-year-old school still stands, a symbol of a future that feels uncertain. Churches are scarce, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are bustling.  It's a mix of old and new, with each house wearing its history differently.

There's a big supermarket owned by a Yemenite family, probably the only Arab family around, surrounded by mostly African American neighbors.  The streets are wide, perfect for kids kicking a football, only pausing to let cars pass. Most folks here have roots that run deep, families who've been around for generations, sharing stories of a time when everyone knew everyone. Even the businesses have stories.  The karate school, once a hot spot, turned into a pharmacy when Hollywood stopped making "Karate Kid" movies. Apparently, pills are the new kicks. There's a small, old movie theater, showing classic films for a song, loved by the older crowd but ignored by the younger generation who crave the latest blockbusters.

The only expressway cuts through the town next door, a constant reminder of the world outside. There was a push to get an exit, championed by the young folks, but the older generation, fiercely protective of their town, convinced the city council to say no. Now, they're building a new high school, but the question of a mascot is a hot topic.  I think a cyborg with a country drawl and a log cabin would perfectly capture the essence of this place: a blend of the old and the new, clinging to tradition while facing an uncertain future.

This neighborhood might not seem like much at first glance. Tucked behind a shopping strip in a residential area, it doesn't scream "desirable living."  But if you venture past the old, forgotten Whole Foods and the hotels that only buzz with life during summer reunions, you'll discover a thriving community hidden in plain sight. 

You'll find a cluster of apartment complexes lined up like carefully disassembled Russian nesting dolls, each nestled beside the other. Some complexes have a shady past, making headlines for less-than-savory dealings, but let’s just say appearances can be deceiving. Just a little further down the road, you'll stumble upon a different world, a secret known only to a select few.  

Across from these complexes sits a quiet community college campus, its sleepy buildings watching over the road. Students shuffle in, bleary-eyed and clutching coffee at 7 am, their arrival greeted by the frustrated honks of commuters who wish they'd stay home.  

The road leads to another residential street, where a park sits on one side and a rehabilitation center rests on the other.  The center boasts a cheerful porch with gently whirring ceiling fans, a stark contrast to the commotion outside. Children’s laughter echoes through the park, mixing with the buzzing of bees in the flower patches. Retired folks stroll with their dogs, eyeing the skateboarders with disapproval and offering polite nods to the teenage girls gossiping by the playground. 

Nearby, a strip mall offers a slice of Americana. A sushi place with cheap eats and a constant flow of customers sits next to a swimming supply store and a nail salon.  You could get your pool ready for summer, get your nails done, and enjoy some hibachi chicken, all in one stop.  

And there's the frozen yogurt shop, the kind where you build your own concoction, perfect for the teens who hang out in the park, their faces smeared with toppings and their lungs filled with vape smoke, convinced they are the coolest kids around. 

This neighborhood is a snapshot of sleepy Southern life, where change moves at a leisurely pace, and time itself seems to slow down.

"Where is everything?" she asked as we drove past endless cornfields stretching as far as the eye could see. I knew she'd be stunned by the vast emptiness of the landscape. She came from a town where the grocery store was just a stone's throw away, she'd never experienced anything like this before.  Overwhelmed by the sea of corn, I told her stories about growing up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally understood where I came from.

Follow this two-lane country road, and you'll reach a quarry filled with water. Just past it lies the small development where I live.  The houses are mostly brick and stucco, each sitting on at least half an acre of land that everyone takes pride in keeping pristine. Springtime bursts with color from the flowers planted each year, mingling with the changing hues of the midwestern trees throughout the seasons. You'll see rows of high-end Mercedes-Benz cars gleaming in the sun after a good wash, parked in each driveway.

As you continue down the road towards my grey stucco house, you'll see my Korean neighbor, always with a friendly smile, tending to his lawn. He spends his entire day mowing, his singing echoing over the hum of the mower. Everyone finds it amusing, but he's truly a kind and unique individual with an interesting past. He used to be a doctor, and now you'll often find him blending into the scenery with his John Deere Zero Turn mower. 

Finally, you'll arrive at my home. In the side yard, geese waddle around, chased by our terrier. Behind the house, a small stream flows into the quarry, where you can hear bullfrogs croaking, the gentle rush of water, and the occasional "moo" from nearby farms.  Cross the handmade wooden bridge, and you'll find a peaceful oasis filled with native trees, herbs, and wildflowers. This is where I spent most of my childhood, building tree forts, "hunting" (mostly chasing) animals, and always finding an adventurous friend to play with. 

Winters in our town can be harsh, but there's a beauty to them. The lush green yard transforms into a stark wilderness. The trees, once adorned with vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers, become bare skeletons of bark. When snow falls, it's like magic, transforming everything into a winter wonderland.  My yard is filled with snow angels made by my sister and towering snowmen. We fought constantly as kids, using snowballs as our weapons. We'd build massive igloo-like forts, armed with branches, ready for battle.  Our winter wonderland was our escape, a place where we could be just carefree kids.

Alright, let me break down Portland for ya. See, "weird" isn't just a word here, it's practically the city motto.  You'll find it spray-painted on buildings that are also pizza joints, bars, music venues, and who knows what else.  Some folks think it's a throwback to the good ol' days, when Portland was more laid-back and affordable. Back when it was a breeding ground for unique subcultures.  But for others, it's an invitation - come on down to Portland, where being a little different is celebrated.  

Look, even with all the Californians moving in and the fancy condos popping up, Portland still holds onto that weird vibe.  It's not about blind acceptance, it's about accepting things that don't quite fit the norm.  We've got our fair share of modern conveniences and problems, just like everywhere else. We buy our stuff from China, we have yoga studios and hipsters, we've got the whole nine yards.  Maybe "weird" means we just take it all a little less seriously.

Take my neighborhood, for example.  You'll see colorful houses, gardens overflowing with flowers, herbs, and veggies, and these magical things called "free boxes" scattered around.  Think of them as sidewalk treasure chests, overflowing with clothes, books, and who knows what else. You never know what you'll find. It's all part of the Portland charm.

But hey, "weird" comes in all shapes and sizes. Some folks wouldn't touch a free box with a ten-foot pole. They're off doing goat yoga or cheering for the Timbers, our local soccer team.  Portland's a melting pot of people chasing their dreams, or at least dreaming about chasing them while enjoying a few too many beers.

Now, let's be real, Portland has its struggles. We've got a drug problem, which often stems from deeper mental health issues.  The constant drizzle and gloomy skies don't help matters.  And homelessness is a huge issue, though no one seems to have a magic solution.  We've got social services, but they're stretched thin, just like everywhere else.  People here, like everywhere else, grapple with feelings of compassion and frustration when it comes to the homeless population.

So, yeah, Portland's weird.  But it's also real.  It's a city full of contradictions, full of people striving and struggling, just like everywhere else in the world.  But somehow, it all works.

The mountains have always been there, standing tall in the north, witnessing every sunrise and sunset. Even when I'm lost in work or life, they remain a constant presence, steadfast and unmoved by the ups and downs of daily life.  On days when stress gets the best of me, they seem to call out to me. When I turn towards them, they offer a sense of peace and strength, helping me to face each day.  I first fell in love with these mountains when I moved here for college. While the university itself has its own beauty in its buildings, ponds, and trees, the mountains hold a special place in my heart.  The town itself is lovely, with charming cafes that fueled countless study sessions. A short walk or bus ride takes you to the downtown area, where faded brick buildings create a sense of history and bustle, reminding you of the nearby city. This vibrant energy doesn't last long, though, as you can quickly escape back to the peaceful small-town atmosphere by passing the library. This blend of contrasting vibes creates a unique charm, inviting exploration and making it easy to create lasting memories.  There are memories of walking past rusty swings in the park with friends after late-night study sessions, and running through the bustling downtown to catch a movie at the fancy theater thanks to a university discount. But there are also harder memories, as there are in every place. The ponds, in particular, can be places of both reflection and tears during those late-night existential crises, which I've had my fair share of. Watching turtles, ducks, and insects go about their lives, each playing a role, made me question my own purpose as I struggled to navigate life's complexities.  So, I walked past the pond, the park, and the quaint little houses that scream "suburbia," until I reached a main street. As the sun rose, bathing the palm trees in its golden light, I realized I was walking north. And there they were, as always: the mountains, reaching towards the sky, a silent reminder of perseverance.

Alright, so you're thinking about checking out Bensonhurst, Brooklyn? Finding it won't be a hassle, trust me. Public transit is a breeze in NYC, and Bensonhurst is right in the thick of it. It's got that classic urban vibe, no question. 

One thing you'll notice right away is the abundance of Asian businesses. Over the past couple of decades, Bensonhurst has become a real melting pot of Asian cultures. You'll practically stumble upon an Asian-owned store every block you walk – supermarkets, laundromats, you name it. Locals swear by these places because the food is top-notch, prices are killer, and it's super convenient. I'm talking four Asian supermarkets within a two-minute walk from where I am!

Now, Bensonhurst isn't just an Asian enclave, mind you. It's a mix of folks from all walks of life – immigrants, first- and second-generation Americans, the whole shebang.  While the Asian-owned businesses are definitely prominent, there's also a recently revamped park nearby that's a real gem. Think ten basketball courts, a huge field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a playground, even a water fountain for the little ones to splash around in.  And just like everywhere in NYC, the park's got a melting pot of people enjoying themselves. 

You won't find any massive corporate towers here, just cozy co-op buildings, condos, and mostly two-family houses. The people are generally friendly, but they're known for being a bit loud. Think cars blasting music, revving engines in the morning – it's definitely not a quiet neighborhood.  

If you're planning a night-time visit, just be aware that while Bensonhurst is generally safe, you never know what you might encounter. There's always a chance you might run into someone looking for trouble, or even some petty theft.  I've personally had some run-ins with bullies in the past, but that was a while back.  Package theft is also a thing here, unfortunately.

And one last thing – forget about the city's "clean up after your dog" rules. Dog waste is everywhere! Seriously, be prepared to dodge it on your way to the train or the supermarket. It's my biggest pet peeve in the entire neighborhood. Watch your step and keep those shoes clean!

My neighborhood is a quirky place, tucked away on a steep hill with hardly any sidewalks. It's nicknamed the "work out hill" because it's a popular spot for joggers, but with no sidewalks you have to share the hilly road with them—a road that's not in the best shape and can be a bit of a hazard!

The neighborhood's got an almost patchwork look, with old, worn-down power lines strung up between houses. The constant rain and storms often knock branches down on them, leading to repairs that leave them looking patched up.  Everywhere you look, there are towering evergreen trees, but surprisingly, most people here despise them. They're constantly trying to chop them down because they block the view of the ocean. That's why so many houses are perched high on the hill, with massive glass second stories that reach for the horizon, craving that ocean vista.

Sunsets are breathtaking here, with the water glowing from below and the sky turning shades of orange. But most days are overcast, so the sunlight filters through a hazy veil. It's often damp and misty, with moss growing on everything—roofs, cars, even railings! I once left my car parked for a month and came back to find it covered in a thick layer of moss—took forever to scrub it off!

There aren't many kids around, but there's a school nearby. The neighborhood is mostly older folks, many of them retired. Instead of kids, it's all about dogs! They're everywhere, lounging in yards or racing down the street.  Be careful, though, because if you leave a door or window open, you might get an unexpected furry visitor!

Rabbits are another neighborhood fixture, much to the chagrin of gardeners who hate them for digging up their plants. My cats, however, delight in the chase and have thinned their ranks considerably. We have the usual assortment of birds: sparrows, hummingbirds, the occasional hawk or eagle, chased away by the neighborhood crows.

There aren't any shops nearby, but if you hike down to the waterfront, there are a few restaurants serving fresh seafood. The beach isn't much to write home about, but the rocks along the shore are fun for launching into the water. The bay itself isn't very wide, so you can easily see the other side even through the mist.

My neighborhood's pretty chill, like a typical suburban spot in a small Tennessee town.  We're right in the middle of things, sandwiched between two state highways, which means there's more traffic than I'd prefer.  But other than that, it's a pretty quiet place. Folks don't move around too much, so I know most of the neighbors. They're all about the usual stuff - yard work, daily chores, that kind of thing. In the winter, we even have a hill in our street where the kids sled. Our house is on the corner, so we're practically the neighborhood watch. We know everyone's comings and goings, and we definitely notice any unfamiliar cars. Some folks like to walk for exercise or take their dogs for a stroll. The kids are always zooming around on their bikes, you know, the usual neighborhood scene.

Since we work from home, we're pretty much always around. It's just me, my wife, and our two daughters, eleven and fourteen. Everyone else is used to seeing us come and go. We're a pretty active family, playing outside even when it's raining. We fire up the grill on our back deck sometimes, and that barbecue smell fills the whole neighborhood. Seems like someone's always mowing their lawn, too. From March to October, the sound of a lawnmower is practically a daily soundtrack. We've got tons of trees, which makes for nice shade, but in the fall, it's all about raking and burning leaves. I gotta say, I love that smell, it's like a signal that fall is officially here.  This year, though, we haven't had much of a winter, so it just feels like a really long fall. 

Our garage is at the back of the house, so we rarely use the front door unless someone's at the door. When I'm working on my truck or other projects in the garage, with the doors open, it feels like I'm more connected to the neighborhood. Holidays are pretty quiet around here, except for Thanksgiving and stuff like Mother's Day and Christmas.  Then, all the families have visitors, and there are cars everywhere. Overall, I really like living here. If it weren't for the traffic, it'd be perfect.

My neighborhood is smack-dab in the middle of the high desert, a world of dirt, dirt, and more dirt.  Unless you've lived here, it's hard to get the feeling of constantly seeing brown. When you *do* see a lawn, you know that person is splashing out big bucks on keeping it green. Back in the 90s when I first moved here, houses were spread out like stars in the night. Now, it's kind of the same, but there are a ton of new additions popping up. Honestly, it's getting more city-like every day, though I guess that's the story everywhere these days. 

The people here are mostly friendly, just like any place, with its good parts and not-so-good parts. My neighborhood is full of nice older folks, which makes it feel pretty chill. As for shopping, it's mostly chains like Food 4 Less and Smart & Final. If you want something upscale, you gotta drive a bit. No Whole Foods or anything like that around here.

Construction seems to be the biggest industry, probably because there's still so much undeveloped land. It's kinda scary, though. I like things the way they are now. I left a big city and don't really want to go back. Speaking of construction, that's what my full-time job is - drywall and T-bar installation.

What I love about where I live is the wildlife. People come to the high desert for all sorts of reasons, but the stark beauty and unique ecosystems are definitely a big draw. It's important for us humans to learn about and respect the animals that call this place home so we can all coexist peacefully. My family and I have adjusted really well. My three kids are obsessed with lizards and desert bugs; right now they're outside trying to catch some specimens.

There are some attractions around here, and Victorville is a pretty good spot for families looking for a different kind of experience. If you can time your visit with the San Bernardino County Fair, it'll be a blast. And if you're feeling adventurous, head over to nearby Wrightwood for some snow-covered mountain fun.  

If you're interested in the history and culture of the high desert, check out the Victor Valley Museum. They've got geological and paleontological stuff, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that tell the story of Victorville.

Let me tell you, my neighborhood is a bit different from most. While others probably talk about houses and yards, mine's more like a college campus. I live in a dorm, and my whole world revolves around that and the surrounding campus.  It's still a neighborhood, though, with its own vibe.

We've got our versions of houses: apartments, regular houses, and dorm buildings. The apartments are usually crammed with 2-4 people per room, with 4-6 rooms per floor.  Then there are the standalone houses, mostly for alumni, but they're pretty rare.  And of course, we have the dorms, which are basically havens for students.

Speaking of students, my neighborhood is a melting pot.  You've got people from all walks of life, all ages, all cultures.  

We've even got our own little shopping center with places to eat, the school store, and a grocery store. Need something? It's probably right here.  And for those who need to unwind, there's a park— kept clean and safe by everyone who calls this place home.

It's not your typical neighborhood, but it's mine, and I wouldn't trade it for the world.

So, I've been living here for about a decade now, and thought I'd share some of my experiences.  When I first moved from Riverdale to Stockbridge with my family, I gotta admit, I was pretty bummed. I missed my old neighborhood and friends, and I even shed a few tears. But my parents wanted what was best for us - a better school, a safer place to live, you know, all the "not ghetto" stuff.  Over time, I adjusted and made new friends, even some enemies, but I never really got to know the neighbors well except for Mr. Glen and his kids, and Dennis for a while, since they lived right next door. They've become like family to me, and I'm really grateful for their presence in my life. 

I remember when my family went to Mr. Glen's wedding (they had a second one!). It was a blast, and it made me think about my own future wedding and giving my future wife the royal treatment. I even caught one of the little decorative straps Ms. Veda, his wife, threw during the ceremony, though sadly, not the bouquet! We danced the night away, and I had a great time hanging out with Marsharii, one of their daughters. Haven't seen her in a while, though. Hope she's doing well.

This neighborhood feels like a maze, but with GPS, I'm finally starting to explore it more. I've ventured out with my friends Kason and Curtis a few times, mostly hanging out at the local park and playing video games.  Those were good times. I also enjoy spending time in nature, it really calms me. Sometimes I bring some sticks from Home Depot to practice my balance, and even my bokken wooden sword for some practice. It's just fun to indulge in my passions.  There's also a basketball and tennis court, though I haven't played either in a while. It's nice to have them there if I ever feel like picking them up again. My dad and my best friend grew up playing tennis with Mr. Graves, and we had a blast, even though he pushed us hard!

Looking back, there are tons of fun memories from this neighborhood, but these are the ones that stand out.  I know the best is yet to come!

My digs are pretty close to the college, which is a major perk.  Mostly apartment buildings around here, but a few decent, not-too-expensive bars and eats to hang out at. One of the bars just got a name change – it's fancier now, but the drinks aren't drastically better.  Most folks here are either students or lower income, since the rent is pretty reasonable.  There are tons of kids 'cause there's an elementary school a hop, skip, and a jump away. I don't know my neighbors too well – I'm cool with that. They're a heavy weed-smokin' bunch, so the building management put an air freshener right outside their door.  We thought it was hilarious, kind of a passive-aggressive move, you know?  Most of the buildings around here are a little old-school, but might have been renovated inside. Down the street, there are these brand-spanking-new apartments, but I'm not a fan.  Cheaply built, but the rent is sky-high.  It's a total scam, but they can get away with it because they're near campus. There's this super cheap joint five minutes away that serves everything on paper plates and most stuff is microwaved. Across the street is a gas station, supposedly a terrible place to work. But the city put some cash into fixing up the road last summer.  Now there's a nice sidewalk, tons of grass, and the whole area looks a bit nicer. My building is tucked away under a canopy of trees – they chopped down a few, so there are stumps, but way more trees here than down the road. Behind my building is another line of trees, then another apartment complex.  I'm on 42nd, but right behind me is 43rd, and that's a rougher patch. The sidewalks are falling apart, buildings look shabby, and there are a lot of trees, probably to hide the shabbiness. Most of the crime in the area happens at an apartment complex on 43rd, but I can't blame them entirely. The buildings across the street from me have their share of crime and a revolving door of residents. But overall, I dig where I live. It's affordable, convenient, with everything I need close by.  The fact that the university is within walking distance and I have two bus stops nearby makes getting around a breeze.

My neighborhood is a collection of charming duplexes arranged on a cul-de-sac, spaced out to resemble individual houses. They all share a distinctive yellow paint job, white porches, and green metal roofs. Most of the residents are friendly, often gathering at the end of driveways for casual chats while the neighborhood kids play. It's a heartwarming sense of community, a refreshing escape from the constant hum of technology that dominates modern life. It feels like stepping back in time, surrounded by fields, trees, blue skies, and fluffy white clouds.  Of course, living in the countryside comes with its quirks. This season, we've been under tornado warnings, and last night, we even heard the sirens!  I ended up seeking shelter in my bathtub, clutching my smallest dog, my purse, and a few pillows. My bigger dog wasn't too keen on the bathroom and stayed in the living room, barking nervously. The neighborhood was eerily quiet except for the sound of hail battering the ground. After the storm passed, the roads practically steamed due to the sudden temperature change. The hail melted instantly upon hitting the hot pavement. As the clouds parted, the sun emerged, and a double rainbow appeared. I grabbed my camera and snapped some pictures to share with my loved ones on Facebook. They were just as amazed as I was. The streets remained quiet for another hour before folks trickled back home. Then, life resumed its usual rhythm – moms and kids outside as dinner cooked.

It's a wonderful community for someone like me who recently moved from New Hampshire to North Carolina. I love the friendly Southern accents everyone speaks with. While all the duplexes look the same on the outside, they differ in size on the inside. Some are surprisingly small, which seems odd.  I enjoy walking through the large field behind my house and strolling down to the non-swimmable pond. I've even spotted deer and hear the booming chorus of a giant bullfrog in the mornings. It's a fantastic place to live, just forty minutes outside Charlotte. Each morning, the sound of roosters crowing from nearby farms greets me. It feels like living in a small, self-contained village. We even have a donkey at a nearby farm whose evening brays let us know he's around. I'm so lucky to have found this hidden gem of a neighborhood.

So, I moved into this neighborhood when I was about to start eighth grade.  Making friends wasn't easy at first, but I eventually became close with a couple of guys—one two houses down and the other on my street. They've moved on since then, but the memories we shared stick with me. Most of the folks who were here when I first arrived are still around, which gives the place a familiar feel.  It's pretty typical suburban stuff—two-story houses everywhere, kids playing outside whenever the weather's decent, and a generally quiet vibe during the week.  

I've never had any issues with anyone here. People generally keep to themselves, but they're always willing to lend a hand if you need it. I've ordered tons of stuff online and never had a package go missing. It's a safe and trustworthy neighborhood.

There's a park just a stone's throw from my house, overflowing with memories.  We used to play basketball, football, and baseball there with the other neighborhood kids. I even got clocked in the nose playing football once—definitely not my most glamorous moment. But the good times far outweigh the bad. Now, whenever I go to the park, it's to hang out with my cousin's kids. They're way younger than me and still love the swings and slides, which brings back a flood of nostalgia. Just thinking about that park takes me right back.

The neighborhood is super diverse, with tons of different cuisines within a short distance. You can find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants all within a mile.  Of course, most folks nowadays just order in through apps like GrubHub and DoorDash.  The usual fast food chains are everywhere, but there are also plenty of pizza places sprinkled around, too.

We have all the necessities covered—dry cleaners, a Walgreens, a CVS, a Jewel-Osco grocery store (a Midwest staple), and even an Indian-owned store for all your homemade curry needs.

Overall, I'm pretty lucky to call this place home. Reading about all the neighborly drama going on elsewhere makes me appreciate the peace and security I have here.

My town, Johnston, is pretty typical for South Carolina.  It's small and quiet, but it plays a big role in the state's agriculture scene. You can't miss their claim to fame: "Peach Capital of the World" proudly sits on the town sign. It's basically one big farm, either bursting with peach trees or grazing cattle. Houses are spread out, mostly two-story affairs with metal roofs or gray shingles to beat the summer heat. They're often tucked back from the road, leaving front yards for animals and crops. In the town center, a single stoplight controls traffic at the four-way intersection, where you'll find all the town's shops. 

For a quick bite, you've got Hong Kong, a family-run Chinese restaurant, Fiesta Mexican, or Gary's, a small burger joint. Sadly, the pizza place closed down recently. There's Maxwell and Halford Drug, a tiny pharmacy famous for its Cherry Coke. Then there's the IGA, a smaller, pricier grocery store.  Even though it's the only one in town, most people head to a Walmart in the nearby town of Batesburg-Leesville for their big grocery hauls. The real star, though, is Dollar General. It's packed from opening to closing with folks grabbing everyday essentials. 

Possibilities Furniture & More, run by a friendly local, is a small furniture store with delivery service. Next door is Clark's Cuts and Kennels, a pet groomer offering daycare, boarding, and all the pampering a pet could want. The doctor's office and the vet are a little outside the main drag, but they're well-equipped to take care of the town's residents.  Johnston Elementary School is the only one in town; after fifth grade, kids head to the neighboring town for middle and high school.

Don't expect any parks or amusement spots here. They are, however, working on a small recreational area to give families more options for fun and attract new residents.  It's definitely a quiet town, so much so that you could easily drive through without even noticing.

My first introduction to this place came through a podcast about missing persons, which was a bit of a shock. I couldn't believe it, considering apartments in the area were going for over a thousand dollars a month.  None of my friends had heard anything about it either. Maybe it's the struggle that keeps things under wraps. I know some of my friends have tough nights, crying themselves to sleep because things are so expensive. But we've learned how to be resourceful over time.  We've come to appreciate the musty scent of flea market finds and secondhand clothes. You learn to prioritize practicality over things that don't really matter when you're an adult. It's like the smell of adulthood itself: dusty magazines piled on a closed piano, lingering on your leather jacket even after you wash it.  Luckily, there are three thrift stores within walking distance. You can start at one end and hit two charity thrift shops, a library, a rare book store, and even a curiosity shop. Downtown is bustling with cars and people every morning, but inside the thrift stores, it's always quiet. No matter how much noise is outside, the stores remain peaceful sanctuaries. It's the perfect place to lose yourself for an afternoon. Every year, the city seems to get even more crowded. Cars and people swarm the streets, a sign of its rapid development. They call it a developing city, headquartered by one of the world's largest e-commerce and delivery empires. It's still growing, still figuring things out. It reminds me of New York City in its early days - everyone focused on their own goals, not really asking much from anyone else.  You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and nobody bats an eye. It's different from the South, where a little concern is seen as genuine care. Here, people mind their own business. You can keep your distance as long as you want, and the city just keeps rolling on like the waves on the beach. It's a vibrant place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur singers upstairs, there's always something happening.  In a way, we have less of an apartment building full of strangers and more of a community of friends. We come together for birthdays, funerals, and whatever else life throws our way, always there to support each other. I feel lucky to be here. I like most of my neighbors, and they're pretty good to me. I try to be considerate, cleaning up after myself and sharing food, and they do the same. We help each other out with mail and other errands. It's nice to see them, and I think they enjoy my company as much as I do theirs. I live in this massive, impersonal modern complex, but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I haven't completely messed up my life.

So, where I live is basically your average, run-of-the-mill suburb. You know, the kind where everyone's got a perfectly manicured lawn and the homeowner's association is breathing down your neck about every little thing.  Every house looks pretty much the same: little patch of grass, some fancy rocks, a short driveway, maybe a tree or two, and a two-car garage.  You drive down the street and it's like a brand new road, no potholes or bumps in sight.  Most houses are single-story, but sometimes you'll see a two-story thrown in for good measure.

Speaking of different, our mailboxes are a bit weird. Instead of individual ones by each house, they're all clustered together at the end of the street like in an apartment building. You gotta use a key to get to your own box, and there are giant lockers for packages too.  You can thank the HOA for that little dose of uniformity.

[REWRITE]

I call a small Midwestern town outside a big city home. My area, on the east side, is the less affluent part of town. You'll see a lot of rented houses and folks earning lower incomes here. But it's not a bad place to be.  My neighbors are all friendly folks who wave hello when I walk by. Crime isn't super high, though it's a bit higher than in other parts of town. We've had a few shootings and even a homicide within a couple blocks of my house over the past ten years. The family next door lost their son in a shooting outside a bar last year, which was a real tragedy. Luckily, we haven't been directly affected by crime, just the occasional item snatched from our porch if we forget to bring it inside.

This town, like many across the country, has been hit hard by the opioid epidemic. We've lost people to fentanyl overdoses, it's been tough.  But there are resources here to help, like addiction recovery centers and Narcan training for families.

Despite the challenges, our town has a lot going for it. My son's elementary school is fantastic – the principal, teachers, and support staff are all amazing.  He has special needs, but he's never been bullied there because the school has such a positive atmosphere.  He loves it! We have a vibrant PTO that organizes lots of events to get families involved and support learning. Since over 20% of our town lives below the poverty line, the school provides free breakfast and lunch for every student, so no kid goes hungry. No one is made to feel less than because they can't afford things – school fees, supplies, and field trips are all very reasonable.

The city council has been working hard to spruce things up, repaving roads, landscaping, and fixing up parks. Most of these improvements have been focused on the downtown and west side, where the shops are and most people drive through. The east side, where I live, seems to get left behind, which isn't fair, but hey.

Overall, I'm happy living here. People are friendly, the schools are great, we have enough shopping options (both big chains and local businesses) to get by, and our house might not be worth much, but it's comfy and does the job. We've lived here for over 16 years, and we can't imagine being anywhere else.

My neighborhood is a melting pot of culture, built on a hill with buildings that whisper stories of the past. I live in a seven-story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and just down the street is a cool arcade bar that pulls in all sorts of folks on warm summer evenings. You'll often see a line snaking down the block on weekends, especially in June and July. A few blocks up, you'll find the nearest city park, surprisingly spacious for this urban area.  Around the park is a concrete wall with tall stairs built in. During the harsh winter months, homeless folks set up their tents in neat rows along the sidewalk and those wide steps, seeking warmth against the biting cold and frequent downpours. Clustering together in the heart of town, rather than out in the open, helps them stay warmer. Plus, they're within easy reach of the only family center for miles, where they can shower and find some comfort.

But what I truly love about this city isn't just the history and architecture that grace its hills, leading down to the ocean. It's the people. You see, Hilltop has a past, a notorious one, as the West Coast's most violent neighborhood. Even decades later, stories circulate about federal agents and the DEA trying to clean up the streets. Those stories echo through generations, reaching newcomers like me. Despite its rough reputation, the residents work hard to keep it clean and cared for. They still have a strong sense of community, a fierce loyalty.  

There's a saying, "If you're white, don't walk around Hilltop after dark."  I think it's a relic of the past, a leftover from a time of fear and prejudice, perhaps even a bit of self-preservation. Maybe it's because I'm dark enough to blend in, or maybe Hilltop sees me as one of their own, someone who understands the underlying tensions that still linger.  We're all reminded of how racism and assumptions can blind people to the truth, even in a city that prides itself on being a melting pot. But one thing is certain: no matter where I go, Hilltop will always feel like home. 

Walking its streets at night, encountering people who offer me a jacket before a wallet, makes me feel alive. It's a place where the laundromat owner stays open late so I can charge my phone when trapped by the rain. It's a place where I've huddled unseen against shop fronts on the bleakest nights, only to have someone stop, meet my eyes, hand me $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.

I live in a small town in rural Michigan, where farmland blends into quaint tourist spots. You won't find any big city chains like malls, Walmart, or even an Applebee's here. Everything requires a drive to get to.  Despite the lack of bustling city life, I live in a breathtaking place surrounded by water. Both Lake Michigan and Lake Charlevoix border my town, offering beaches practically everywhere you go.

My neighborhood embodies the classic small-town feel. Houses aren't crammed together, and they're not cookie-cutter designs. They're older homes, some modernized, others retaining their original charm. Most have full basements visible from the street, and you'll find a mix of architectural styles and colors. Yards are common, with trampolines, playsets, gardens, and even fences for animals. 

It's a neighborhood of hardworking folks – families raising children or enjoying life after raising them. Kids are constantly running around, and you'll see people walking dogs, biking, and rollerblading. Neighbors know each other, and a sense of community prevails. You'll see someone grilling and wave back, or smile at a dog walker passing by. Lawns are well-maintained, with no piles of leaves or overgrown greenery. 

While not picture-perfect, it's a place where you can picture raising a family. It's quiet, peaceful, and safe.  It's not about stunning aesthetics, but about providing a sense of belonging and security. 

Within walking distance, you'll find the county sheriff's department, jail, health department, and recycling center, all serving the community. Nearby, baseball and softball fields echo with the sounds of games, and our small town airport provides a constant soundtrack of planes taking off and landing. You can even walk to the local ice cream parlor, or if you're feeling adventurous, make it downtown. My kids can easily bike to the park, just eight blocks away. 

It's a truly great place to call home.

original_texts:
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
You might pass it up on first glance - after all, it is a residential area behind a shopping strip, not a place one would assume there are places to live. At least, not places most people would want to live. But if you go behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk back behind the hotels which are only occupied annually aside from a few stints in the summertime for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. Within these communities, on these streets, are a handful of apartment complex - situated next to each other carefully like Russian nesting dolls that have been scrupulously, carefully taken apart and set beside each other in a line down the road, piecemeal. The first apartments you come upon are ones which have been on the news for some fairly unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on those too much - appearances, after all, can be deceiving. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from those complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days attendance is higher. The road t-bones into another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
The first thing you have to understand about Portland, Oregon is the definition of "weird". The unofficial town slogan, on the back of a building that serves as a pizza joint, bar, music venue, strip club, and skirts the law on at least half of these endeavors, is "Keep Portland Weird". To some, this is a small cry to remember the Portland of the 90's and early 2000's, a Portland that was less known and less expensive, generating creative and unique subcultures. To others, it is a beckoning call - come to Portland, where people will still call you weird, but as a compliment this time. Despite the influx of affluent Californians and the constant construction of condominiums to house these Californians, Portland is still weird. Weird does not mean always accepting, but it does mean accepting of things that are normally not accepted. Weird does not mean we do not have modern conveniences and modern fights. Like the rest of the country, we buy most of our things from China. There are a million ways of being weird, of being not normal, but Portland has plenty of normal. Portland has yoga and hipsters and business professionals. Perhaps weird means we just take all of this less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many Portland neighborhoods, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers and herbs and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summertime. Free boxes are traditionally cardboard boxes containing items someone is getting rid of, but they can be plastic bags or boxes. They contain something magical, a treasure just perfect for the person wandering by, a surprising amount of the time. Free boxes tend to have clothes and books, but they can have anything. The magical potential of walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about. That is, what Portland is all about to me, but I am just one variety of weird among thousands. Some people I live among would never dream of picking their clothes out of a box on the sidewalk. Those people go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with real live goats) or Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all sorts of things. Portland is full of people who pursue our dreams, or dream about pursuing our dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug problems tend to be (at their root) mental health problems, and the constant rain through much of the year, plus the dreary clouds, appear to be a contributor. Portland has a homelessness problem too, which no one seems to know what to do with. The homeless population is drawn by the social services Portland offers, better than in most parts of the country, but our services are insufficient, as in all parts of the country. The non-homeless population wavers between care and hatred. In this, we are not weird at all.
The mountains are always there. In the north, bearing witness to the sun’s journey every dawn and every dusk. No matter how much I forget about them or how caught up with work and life I am to notice, they are there, unwavering, unopposed, and unphased by life’s tribulations. Then on days when I am the most stressed and wound, they demand to be seen, and when I turn to them they let me rest my anxious soul, lending me some strength to go on, one day at a time. I first moved here when I started my undergrad, and the mountains to the north of campus where what first captivated me. Sure, the university has its own share of breathtaking sights in buildings and ponds and trees, which have their own share of my heart, but it’s the mountains that really holds its throne. The rest of the town is beautiful in its own right. There are countless cafés that were home to many hours of caffeine fueled cramming. One can walk or take the bus just a little further to the downtown area and be enveloped in an aura of antiquity by the faded colored bricks that line restaurants and office buildings. It is here that this seemingly suburban town shows as much bustle and vigor as it’s neighboring urban city. This doesn’t last for many blocks though, as one can escape, once again, to the serene small town by passing the library. This dichotomy of atmospheres in such proximity truly give this city a wonderous vibe as if it was beckoning to be explored. With this, it is easy to create many a cherished memory, each in association with a certain part of town. Whether it is walking past the rusted swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or running through the busy downtown to catch the movie in the fancy theater for which the university provided tickets. Alas, it is also home to many harsh memories, as all places are bound to be in life. The ponds, in particular, can be a rather fitting place for reflection as well as crying sessions at two in the morning in the middle of an existential crisis. The latter of which, I have more experience in. While watching the turtles and ducks and insects live out their lives, each with some contribution or role, I couldn’t help but wonder about my own sense of purpose as I struggled to navigate this mystery called life. So, I walked past the pond, and past the park and little houses that scream of suburbia, until I reached a main street. It was then that sun shined its brilliant rays atop the palm trees, painting the sky along the way, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, they were there, as they had always been. The sturdy overbearing mountains grazed the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building in the horizon, and as if speaking without words, stirred in me my sense of perseverance.
If you are planning on visiting Bensonhurt, Brooklyn, you will not have a difficult time finding it! Public transportation is very accessible and is one of the most popular forms of transportation in New York City. Bensonhurt is a fairly urban neighborhood, so you will still feel as if you are in New York City. During your visit, be prepared to see the various Asian stores all around. Over the past two decades, Bensonhurt has received an influx of Asian inhabitants. Because of this, you will see an Asian-owned store at least every block as you are walking. Most popular are supermarkets and laundromats. Coincidentally, these businesses are very popular among local residents, as quality of food in the supermarkets are superb, the prices are much cheaper, and finally yet importantly, it is very convenient. Just nearby where I am, there are four Asian supermarkets within two minutes of walking distance from each other. This just adds to the convenience of accessing grocery. I’m not saying Bensonhurst is purely populated by Asian inhabitants, though. It is quite diverse all around, with immigrants and their first-generation and second-generation American children here. Most of the large and popular businesses in the local area are Asian owned. In addition to these Asian owned businesses, there is also a recently renovated park nearby, which has around ten basketball courts, a large field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a playground for kids, and even a water fountain for kids to enjoy water in the summer. Since we are in New York City, of course the parks are very diverse. You will see all sorts of diversity here, able to play and get along well. In this neighborhood, there aren’t many large corporate buildings. The only buildings you’d find are ones for co-op living, or condominium apartments. The majority of living spaces here are two-family houses though. Most of the people are quite nice, however, very noisy. Every day, you’d hear cars blasting their music as they drive by your house, or constantly flooring the gas on their cars which will wake you up in the morning. If you are planning on visiting during night time, you should be on your guard. This neighborhood is fairly safe, but people are unpredictable. You may run into people who want to start trouble for no reason, bullies and thieves. I myself have been bullied in this neighborhood in the past via physical assault, but this was many years ago. Another recent incident involved package stealing. Although a common thing, there are package thieves in this neighborhood. Last but not least, although New York City has a fine for people not cleaning up after their dogs, people don’t follow the rules here. Every morning, you will see at least one dog waste on your way to the train station, or on your way to the supermarket. My biggest pet peeve is dog waste on the floor everywhere I go in this neighborhood. Be careful and keep your shoes clean!
There aren't many sidewalks where I live. Everything seems to flow downward, and my house sits right at the crest of the steepest hill in the neighborhood. People call it the "work out hill" because so many joggers like to run up it during their daily work out. As there aren't any sidewalks at all on my street everyone walks on the road. There road is pitted in a few places and can feel a bit hazardous to drive on. Some of the telephone and electric wires strung up around the block at tattered looking. It rains and storms a lot in our area, so branches and other debris often strike down the power lines and the constant repairs make them look checkered and patchwork-y. There's many tall evergreen trees all around everywhere you look. But people here hate the trees. They strive to cut down as many as possible because the trees obstruct the view of the ocean. That's why many of the houses are built so high up on the hill, with huge glass-fronted second stories that loom up one after the other to take in the view of the bay. It's gorgeous around sunset when the water seems to get lit up from below and the sky turns orange. It's cloudy more often than not, though, so you end up seeing most of the sunlight through a haze. Most days are overcast and damp. Moss grows on everything it can: roofs, cars, and railings. I once left my car parked out in my driveway for a month and when I went out to use it, it had turned green and furry with moss. Took me three hours to scrap it all off. There aren't that many children around where I live, though there's a school only a few blocks away. Most of the people in my neighborhood are older, many of them retired. Instead of kids, people have dogs. It's common to see them sitting out in people's lawns or racing down the street after each other. If you leave a door or window open you risk having them sneak into your house. I found one once in my living room and had to shoo it back out the front door. Rabbits run wild around the area. Some of them are good sized, and the gardeners hate them because the dig up the roots of plants and burrow into people's lawns. My cats love them though, and have hunted most of them out of our neighborhood. We also get the usual assortment of birds: small sparrows and hummingbirds, and the occasional hawk or eagle sometimes swoops by until the neighborhood crows chase it off. There aren't any stores around, but if you hike downhill to the waterfront there's a few restaurants that serve fresh seafood. There isn't much of a beach down there, but the rocks along the shore are fun to hurl into the water. The bay itself isn't very wide. You can see the opposite shoreline clearly even through the mist on most days.
I live in a typical suburb area in a small southern town in Tennessee. It's a connecting street between two state highways, so we get a bit more traffic on the street than I'd like, but other than that, it's a quiet neighborhood. There's not too many folks that move in and out, so I've grown used to most of the people that live in the neighborhood. People busy themselves with yard work and other daily chores for the most part. In the winter, we sled down a hill on our side street. We live in a house at the front corner of our street, so we see everyone coming and going all day long and are familiar with the cars that people drive around here. Whenever we see a strange vehicle, we tend to take note of it. Some of the neighbors go walking for exercise or just to walk their dogs. Kids play on their bikes and all that you would expect from that. We are at home a lot since we work from our house. There are four of us, Myself and my Wife, and two Daughters ages eleven and fourteen. So, I'd say that everyone else is used to us coming and going as well. We get outside and play, sometimes even in the rain. Once in a while we grill outside on our back deck and it's always a pleasant smell from the barbecue and all. It seems that there's always someone cutting grass around here and you can hear a lawn mower nearly every day from March through about October, when the grass finally stops growing. We have a lot of trees in our neighborhood as it was originally a wooded area, so there's lots of shade, but there's always a lot of leaves in the Fall as well. So, that means raking and burning the leaves on a yearly basis. I like the smell of burning leaves too, so that's always a nice sign that Fall has arrived. Lately, we've not been having much Winter to speak of, so it just feels like a long Fall. Our garage is at the back of our house, so we seldom use the front door of our house unless someone knocks on the door, which is rare. I like to work in the garage on my truck or other projects from time to time and when I have the garage doors open, it feels like I'm more tuned into the neighborhood. On holidays it is pretty quiet around here. Thanksgiving sees some of the neighborhood families visiting with people from out of town and there are extra cars parked everywhere during that time of year. It's the same at other holidays like Mother's day and Christmas. All in all, I like living here. If it weren't a through street, it would be perfect.
My neighborhood is in the smack middle of the high desert, where there is dirt, dirt and more dirt. Unless someone has actually experienced living here, they probably donâ€™t really understand the feeling of always seeing brown , and when you do see a lawn, you know that person is spending a fortune on lawn care. When I first lived here in the 90s, houses were spread out far and wide. Now it is pretty much the same way by there are a lot of new additions. Honestly this place looks more and more like a city everyday, but supposed most places are changing the same way. Most of the time the people are very friendly, but just like any city you have your good parts and bad. In my neighborhood I'm surrounded by friendly old people iI guess it's a nicer neighborhood. The stores in this place are pretty much the store who have chains, like food for less and smart and final. If you want uscale you have to travel I never really see any whole foods or stores of that nature. The jobs that are most prominent in my city I would say not based on any official demographics, is construction. I think this is on account of this city is still not very developed, there is still a lot of wide open spaces to build. That kind of scares me, I like things the way they are now. I left a big city and I'm not keen on going back. Speaking of construction this was the field my full time job is located in, i am a drywall and T-bar instalator. What I like about my home is the different animals. People come to the high desert for many reasons, not the least of which is the stark beauty of the desert itself. High desert climate and topography have created challenging ecosystems which need protecting and which are home to different types of wildlife. Human residents of the high desert should take the time to learn about the non-human residents who share this environment in order to co-exist safely and harmoniously. My family and I have adapted very well to the wildlife. I have three children and they are all obsessed with lizards and dessert bugs, as I am writing this now they are outside trying to catch different specimens. As far as attractions goes we have some. Additionally, Victorville is a good place for families to experience the desert. It can generate a different experience. If you can, plan your visit to coincide with its annual event: the San Bernardino County Fair. The fair will enrich your visit with the right mix of activities and fun the Victorville way. Pop by the nearby Wrightwood to see the snow covered mountains and take some winter sports lessons to finish out your visit. Interested in the natural history and culture of the high desert ecosystem? The Victor Valley Museum includes geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that tell the story of the development of society and industry of Victorville.
When asked to describe my neighborhood, I'm sure that my answer is somewhat unique. While others who respond to this are most likely homeowners with their own individual lives, my situation is a tad bit different. I consider my neighborhood to be the college campus that I stay on, and the people that live in my dormitory to be my community. I also consider the surrounding campus to be my neighborhood, albeit to a lesser extent. Despite this peculiarity, my neighborhood shares some commonalities with the more conventional ideas about a neighborhood. Just like any conventional neighborhood, the neighborhood I stay in has houses, people, stores and parks. Let us begin by discussing the "houses" that comprise my neighborhood. Before I begin to explore the houses in my neighborhood, it would be best to clarify the types of house that can be found in my neighborhood. There are three types of housing in my immediate vicinity, the apartments, the actual houses, and the dormitory houses. First, In the apartments, there are usually between 2-4 people in any given room, and there are about 4-6 rooms on each floor. The most common building type can house about 2 floors, so on average, there are 20 or so people living in each building. Second, are the actual houses that are available for anyone with an affiliation to the school to rent. Typically these are 2-4 bedroom setups that usually have alumni living in them. However, there are only a handful of these types of houses spread throughout the neighborhood, as they are less efficient. Finally, there are the typical dorm rooms which house 100's of students. In these, you have two people sharing a room with some exception, and it is the most common type of housing in my neighborhood. With housing covered we are ready to move on to the people. My school prides itself on diversity and this is reflected in the makeup of my neighborhood. There are people from all cultures and ages that live in my neighborhood. Most of the professional staff live in the houses that are placed in the neighborhood, whereas the newer students stay in the dormitory style housing and the older students stay in the apartment-style housing. The people in this neighborhood can't be done justice by simply talking about them, so it would be best to simply move on to the stores and parks in my neighborhood. Since my school really is it's own self-contained neighborhood, it has a plethora of stores and a single park. The stores are a mix of dining options that would be found in any other neighborhood, and the schools own unique brand of clothing and grocery stores. As such, anything that is needed can be found within my neighborhood's boundaries! Additionally, the park in my neighborhood is a playground for all the diverse people in my neighborhood, it is kept clean and free of crime by all the members of my neighborhood!
Well, considering that I’ve been here for about 10 years, I guess I can share what I know. First off, I was pretty sad when I first came to my neighborhood. I came from Riverdale to Stockbridge, and I’m not going to lie, I cried, because I missed them and I loved them.. but my mom and dad wanted the best for me and my little sister, so we moved to a better location for housing, a better high school, everything was considered “not ghetto” when we moved to our new neighborhood. Throughout the years, I got used to it, and made some new friends, and some new enemies too in school. I never really truly got to know my neighbors throughout the years, except Mr. Glen and his children, as well as Dennis for a bit, both being right next to us. They have been enjoyable people that I almost can consider as family in some ways, and I truly do appreciate them. I remember when me, mom, dad, and my sister went to Mr. Glen’s wedding (They got re-married) It was really fun and enjoyable to say the least, and something I’m looking forward to someday, as I build my wealth and give my future wife the life of a Queen. When Mr. Glen’s wife, Ms. Veda, took off the white little strap on her leg and threw it, I caught it! Sadly I didn’t catch the flowers! We all danced the night away, and I really enjoyed having a good time with Marsharii, one of their daughters. I haven’t seen her since though. I hope she’s moved on to bigger and better things. The neighborhood itself is like a maze, although now I have a GPS, so I can take more time to explore it. I’ve only went so far, and that is when I’ve hung out with my friends Kason and Curtis. We all used to play video games alot, and just enjoy life to the fullest as much as we could. Sometimes I would go to the park and enjoy nature, which soothes my soul. It gives me a sense of calmness and peace these days. I’ll also bring some sticks that I bought from home depot and just practice my balance, And bring my bokken wooden sword if I can,. I have fun enjoying what I love to do.
